title: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick heckled on Colbert’s ‘Late Show’
text:
Controversy followed Uber’s Travis Kalanick to the taping of Thursday’s “Late Show,” as heckling disrupted the CEO’s appearance on the late-night talk show hosted by Stephen Colbert.
Colbert, an improv veteran who just took the show’s reins on Tuesday, is drawing praise for how he handled the interruptions.
As Colbert interviewed Kalanick, a heckler shouted and claimed the ride-sharing startup is destroying jobs in the taxi industry.
It was “interesting” how Colbert handled the protest, said Kristin Condon, an audience member who witnessed the heckling, in an interview with CNN. “Colbert was really respectful ... and allowed it to be an issue rather than just silencing it,” she said, according to CNN’s report , which added that the exchange didn't air.
Colbert let the protester speak before saying he had prepared a similar question on his cue cards, according to a report by Business Insider .
Uber—described as one of the most aggressive and disruptive of an emerging batch of privately held tech companies boasting billion-dollar valuations—isn’t new to controversy. Earlier this week, taxi drivers in Australia staged a protest in Melbourne against the startup, while São Paulo’s city council banned the use of Uber in Brazil’s largest city.
For his part, Kalanick defended his company by saying it paid better salaries and offered more flexible hours than the traditional taxi industry, media reports said.
One Twitter user who said she was in the audience applauded Colbert’s approach to the protest:
But I understand why they didn't show it all. I'm just glad I got to witness it and see in person just how phenomenal Stephen Colbert is.
— Sarah (@falpal_sarah) September 11, 2015 Kalanick appeared on Thursday’s show along with Joe Biden .
Earlier in the week, Tesla’s TSLA, +0.15% Elon Musk and Jeb Bush faced Colbert’s questions.
MarketWatch has written about questions that Colbert should have asked in his first week helming “The Late Show,” as well as covered investing lessons from “The Colbert Report,” his erstwhile Comedy Central show.
